Legal_Issue: Whether sections 14.01 and 14.02 of the Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act violate trustees' rights to due process and an independent and impartial tribunal
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: The Superintendent of Bankruptcy has authority to investigate, prosecute, and adjudicate misconduct by bankruptcy trustees; applicants alleged a reasonable apprehension of bias due to lack of separation of functions
Remedy_Requested: Declaration that sections 14.01 and 14.02 are unconstitutional
Court_Ruling: The disciplinary provisions do not infringe on rights under the Canadian Bill of Rights or Charter; sufficient procedural safeguards exist
Defendant_Behavior: Superintendent exercising investigative, prosecutorial, and adjudicative functions
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged violation of right to an independent and impartial tribunal and procedural fairness
Legal_Standard: Independence and impartiality of decision-making body
Assessment_Factor: Delegation of adjudicative functions to external lawyers
Availability of Federal Court assistance in compelling witnesses
Applicable_Legislation: Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act, sections 14.01 and 14.02
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of administrative decision-making process
Review_Standard: Standard of correctness for constitutional questions
Evidence_Used: Structural design of the disciplinary process
Practice of delegating adjudication to external counsel
Application_Basis: Constitutional challenge based on alleged breach of Charter and Bill of Rights protections
Evidence_Assessed: Operational practices within the Office of the Superintendent of Bankruptcy
Governing_Rule: Combining investigative, prosecutorial, and adjudicative roles does not automatically result in bias if structural safeguards ensure independence
Outcome: Costs awarded to Attorney General of Canada
Harm_Assessment: No demonstrated harm to procedural fairness or impartiality
Cause_Description: Trustees challenged the constitutionality of the internal disciplinary process administered by the Superintendent of Bankruptcy
Evidence_Handling: Court examined institutional practices to assess functional separation
Legal_Provision: Sections 14.01 and 14.02, Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act
Evidence_Assessment: Court found practices mitigate risk of bias
Decision_Rationale: Sufficient separation of functions in practice; external adjudicators used; judicial oversight available
